tagger
Class TagRepositoryImpl

java.lang.Object
  tagger.TagRepositoryImpl
All Implemented Interfaces:
TagRepository
public class TagRepositoryImpl
extends java.lang.Object
implements TagRepository

This class represents a tag repository - which is a repository associating files to tags and uses events to keep track of those files.

Author:
Or Shwartz, Itay Evron

Deletes all the tags and files in the repository

processFileChangeTagging

public void processFileChangeTagging(FileEvent fileEvent)
This Method gets a fileEvent and responds to it according to the event the given FileEvent contains There are four cases : file created : the method then tags the given file using the auto-taggers file modified : the method untag all the tags from the given file then do the same as in CREATED case file deleted : the method removes the file from the repository reboot process : the method checks if the file is in the repository and the last time when it's modified, then tagging it

Specified by:
processFileChangeTagging in interface TagRepository
Parameters:
fileEvent - : a given event

CaseCreated

private java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> CaseCreated(java.nio.file.Path file)
This method is used to prevent double-code in the created and reboot cases in the processFileChangeTagging method. The method uses the available auto-taggers algorithms to tag the given file

Parameters:
file - : a file to tag
Returns:
a Collection of tags(Strings) that the file will be tagged with

setAutoTaggers

public void setAutoTaggers(java.util.Map<java.io.File,AutoTagger> autoTaggers)
Sets the automatic tagging to use the given automatic taggers.

Specified by:
setAutoTaggers in interface TagRepository
Parameters:
autoTaggers - Automatic taggers to use.

getAutoTaggers

public java.util.Map<java.io.File,AutoTagger> getAutoTaggers()
Gets the automatic taggers in use.

Specified by:
getAutoTaggers in interface TagRepository
Returns:
Automatic taggers used. This view of the automatic taggers can be changed and will be affected in the tagger.
